docs.lead_paragraph: Since the passage in 1971 of the National Cancer Act, the Federal Government has put $8 billion into the effort to conquer cancer. With the money, however, the cancer research establishment has received repeated reprimands from Congressional and consumer watchdogs for failing to make dramatic inroads against the leading cancer killers. Where, observers ask, is the promised cancer cure? Critics have further accused the National Cancer Institute, which directs the program and decides how to spend a $1 billion annual budget, of overemphasizing some areas of research, such as cancercausing viruses, and underfunding others that could have a greater payoff, such as environmental and nutritional causes of cancer. Scientists outside the research ''establishment'' have contended that the Government has ignored mavericks with claims for unorthodox ideas and pursued hypotheses that will make piddling advances in the fight against cancer, the nation's second leading cause of death.
